description.narrative:
Plans d’assistance technique ciblée aux pays L’assistance technique ciblée aux pays (TCA) est octroyée sous forme de ressources destinées aux partenaires présents dans les pays. La TCA est un élément du cadre d’engagement avec les partenaires (PEF) de Gavi. Le plan de TCA d’un pays est établie selon les besoins exprimés du dit pays lors de l’évaluation conjointe. Un plan comprend une liste d’activités, d’étapes clés, et un budget pour une année dite. L’assistance technique est un soutien non financier fourni par des spécialistes. Elle peut revêtir plusieurs formes : partage d’information et de savoir-faire, formation et services-conseils.
L’assistance technique fournie dans le cadre du PEF est appelée aide ciblée aux pays. Ce type de soutien vise principalement à payer le personnel basé en permanence dans les bureaux pays des partenaires. Il repose sur la demande et les besoins identifiés par les pays eux-mêmes.

Targeted country assistance (TCA) are resources provided to in-country partners under Gavi’s partners’ engagement framework (PEF). A country’s TCA plan is based on needs expressed by the country during the joint appraisal discussions. It includes sets of activities, milestones and budget for a given year.Technical assistance is non-financial support provided by specialists. It can take the form of sharing information and expertise, training and consulting services.
The technical assistance provided through PEF is called targeted country assistance (TCA). This type of support mainly consists of staff permanently based in partners’ country offices. It is based on the demand and needs identified by the countries themselves.

Guidance on the role of expanded partners in the provision of targeted country assistance

title.narrative: Directives concernant le processus mis en place au titre de l’aide ciblée aux pays dans le cadre du PEF

description.narrative: A travers le cadre d’engagement avec les partenaires, les partenaires de l’Alliance du Vaccin soutiennent les activités de vaccination au niveau national
Gavi’s targeted country assistance aims to share our partners’ specialist skills with the countries we support

title.narrative: À propos de l’aide ciblée aux pays

description.narrative: L’aide ciblée aux pays de Gavi vise à partager les compétences spécialisées de nos partenaires avec les pays que nous soutenons
Through the partners’ engagement framework, Vaccine Alliance partners support countries’ immunisation activities

condition.narrative: Conditions are detailed in the Partners’ engagement framework
Les conditions sont détaillées dans le cadre d'engagement des partenaires

title.narrative: Progress and final report submitted and satisfactory

target.value: Timely and quality 6 monthly technical and financial report developed

comment.narrative: 6 monthly financial report was submitted to Gavi on mid_August 2021 and 6 monthly technical reports were submitted on time.

target.value: Timely and quality 6 monthly technical and financial report developed

comment.narrative: 6 monthly financial report was submitted to Gavi on mid_February 2021 and 6 monthly technical reports were submitted on time. But due to military takeover and all MoHS EPI focals are on CDM, multi-stakeholder dialogue could not be submitted yet.

target.value: Monitor and provide technical assistance to the implementation of eLMIS immunization module at central, sub-depots and townships for immunization module

comment.narrative: An agreement was signed with Clinton Health Access Initiatives (CHAI), Myanmar to implement the immunization eLMIS in mid February. However, due to political instability following military d'état, routine immunization activities were largely disrupted across the country. In the meantime CHAI technical team with support of UNICEF continued technical scope of work. This included reviewing functional requirements of vaccine logistics information system of the program to inform the customization in mSupply platform and dashboard development. To support this, CHAI formed and organized informal supply chain technical working group meetings with supply partners like Chemonics, Zenith Tri for coordination and sharing the insights of eLMIS. Efforts were made to some extent, but CHAI management team is handling enormous impediments for making initial operational engagement with the ministry's focal. If the meeting outcome with the respective focal within the MoH is positive, the adjusted costed workplan will be further discussed and prepared. Due to country's political situation with many limitations, UNICEF had to put on hold recruitment of eLMIS national consultant.

target.value: Provide technical assistance in roll out of GIS based microplanning in 2 states/regions

comment.narrative: Integrated supervisory checklists were developed and orientation meetings were conducted to health staff in 2020. The regular supportive supervisions as well as review meetings could not be carried out as planned in 2020. Because of local COVID-19 outbreak starting from March 23, 2020, immunization services were disrupted partly due to mobilization of health staff for COVID-19 surveillance and response activities and partly due to routine immunization was temporarily stopped in all townships between April and May 2020 and ceased again in 74 stay-at home townships starting from early September 2020 to December 2020 due to second wave of COVID-19 infection. The limitations was further challenged by the country's political situation after military take over in 1st February 2021 which was followed by mass civil disobedience movement by the government staff at all levels. When the country's situation improves and the routine immunization services are resumed, this would be one of the areas to be revitalized and strengthened together with national immunization program. The GIS project rolled out in 2 states (Yangon and Kayah)

title.narrative: Review lessons learned from Dose 1 and planning for Dose 2

target.value: Provide technical assistance to MOH, WHO-CO, and UNICEF-CO with nationwide HPV vaccine introduction.Support WHO with planning and leading in-country stakeholder meetings, readiness assessment pre-launch, and monitor vaccine introduction. Plan for post-introduction evaluation of national HPV vaccine introduction following first cohort dose 2.

comment.narrative: CDC provided TA for national introduction, planning, stakeholder meetings and readiness assessment. They introduced in October 2020 with the next vaccination (and PIE) planned for Fall of 2021. There have been significant delays due to COVID-19 and in-country political challenges. Because of this, we do not have any updates beyond this or plans to support in the next few months. All originally planned activities have been completed except for the PIE (this is not currently planned due to country-specific issues). CDC does plan to provide remote support for the PIE if/when it is planned in the future.

target.value: Provide technical assistance to MOH, WHO-CO, and UNICEF-CO with nationwide HPV vaccine introduction.Support WHO with planning and leading in-country stakeholder meetings, readiness assessment pre-launch, and monitor vaccine introduction. Plan for post-introduction evaluation of national HPV vaccine introduction following first cohort dose 2.

comment.narrative: CDC provided TA for national introduction, planning, stakeholder meetings and readiness assessment. They introduced in October 2020 with the next vaccination (and PIE) planned for Fall of 2021. There have been significant delays due to COVID-19 and in-country political challenges. Because of this, we do not have any updates beyond this or plans to support in the next few months. All originally planned activities have been completed except for the PIE (this is not currently planned due to country-specific issues). CDC does plan to provide remote support for the PIE if/when it is planned in the future.

target.value: Support for Rota and intussusception Surveillance.

comment.narrative: As usual, WHO supported Rota and intussusception surveillance at 4 hospitals during 2020 and the surveillance report was developed by Department of Medical Research in January 2021. Because of the country situation after the military takeover, there was effect on the rota and intussusception surveillance studies. The responsible person from DMR is on CDM and WHO could not support yet for 2021. The study data may not cover the whole picture of post vaccinations scenario although diarrhea hospitalization was reduced to half after introduction of rotavirus vaccine in February 2020. Therefore, it is recommended to keep carrying out surveillance to get data on vaccine effectiveness.

target.value: Support for Rota and intussusception Surveillance.

comment.narrative: As usual, WHO supported Rota and intussusception surveillance at 4 hospitals during 2020 and the surveillance report was developed by Department of Medical Research in January 2021. Because of the country situation after the military takeover, there was effect on the rota and intussusception surveillance studies. The responsible person from DMR is on CDM and WHO could not support yet for 2021. The study data may not cover the whole picture of post vaccinations scenario although diarrhea hospitalization was reduced to half after introduction of rotavirus vaccine in February 2020. Therefore, it is recommended to keep carrying out surveillance to get data on vaccine effectiveness.

target.value: Support for Rota and intussusception Surveillance.

comment.narrative: Rota and intussusception surveillance was conducted at 4 hospitals during 2020 and the final report was developed by Department of Medical Research in 2021. Since the responsible person from DMR is on CDM and the surveillance could not be conducted for 2021.

title.narrative: Smooth implementation of COVID_19 vaccination roll out in the country

target.value: Technical support for COVID_19 vaccination introduction and Post Introduction Evaluation of HPV vaccination

comment.narrative: COVID_19 vaccination is being conducted by MoH, targeting 24 priority groups currently. WCO EPI is providing technical support through providing latest technical documents and provide suggestions to improve the COVID_19 vaccination activities. In addition, to cover missed community, WHO together with UNICEF and development partners are trying to get MOH consensus for COVID_19 vaccination by EHOs and private sectors by providing inputs from private health facility assessment for immunization.

target.value: HPV vaccine introduction and post introduction evaluations of newly introduced vaccines

comment.narrative: Although HPV PIE was planned to conduct during 2021, it could not be conducted due to COVID_19 outbreak and changed political situation in the country.

target.value: HPV vaccine introduction and post introduction evaluations of newly introduced vaccines

comment.narrative: The second dose of HPV vaccine will be due on October 2021 and it is expected to be conducted timely and systematically. The preparatory activities to be started soon. Post introduction evaluation on Rota vaccine could not be conduced as planned in early 2021.

target.value: HPV vaccine introduction and post introduction evaluations of newly introduced vaccines

comment.narrative: The second dose of HPV vaccine will be due on October 2021 and it is expected to be conducted timely and systematically. The preparatory activities to be started soon. Post introduction evaluation on Rota vaccine could not be conduced as planned in early 2021.

target.value: Technical support for improvement of data quality for childhood immunization and COVID_19 vaccination; and to continue support rota and intussusception surveillance

comment.narrative: Completed the IFA software upgrading and dashboard development. SOP on IFA software is under development. Software installation was done for RSO network and conducted training to admin assistants. It is due to shortage of human resources at State/Regional data focal persons, installation and training could not be conducted for state/regional health departments.

target.value: Technical support for improvement of data quality for childhood immunization and COVID_19 vaccination; and to continue support rota and intussusception surveillance

comment.narrative: Completed the IFA software upgrading and dashboard development. Software installation was done for RSO network and conducted training to admin assistants.

target.value: Technical support for improvement of data quality for childhood immunization and COVID_19 vaccination; and to continue support rota and intussusception surveillance

comment.narrative: WHO has provided technical support for upgrading of IFA software Version 1 (stand alone) to Version 2 (software extension, expand the network, online dash board and data sharing) to improve the sensitivity of VPD surveillance data and to respond the vaccine preventable diseases effectively and efficiently in a timely manner. Almost all preparatory activities are completed but due to current political situation, training and installation at states/regions are delayed.

title.narrative: Report of GIS implementation research of Yangon pilot project

target.value: Implementation research for GIS pilot project in Yangon to support rollout of GIS for EPI microplanning

comment.narrative: Due to health workers' involvement in civil disobedience movement following military takeover on February 1, 2021, the IRB review process and subsequent implementation of implementation research has to be postponed. The resumption of the activity will be depended on the return of health workers to health facilities as well as on the normalization of in-country political situation.

title.narrative: Service delivery related barriers of missed communities to access immunisation services identified and prioritized

target.value: Provided technical support in the planning, implementation and monitoring of activities to reach missed/underserved communities, for routine immunization services inlcuding integrated Primarcy Health Care Services

comment.narrative: Due to political changes in February 2021, routine immunization activities has been suspended for about 5 months in almost all townships including EHO areas and underserved areas. WHO and UNICEF has already developed the immunization revitalization plan including the COVID_19 vaccine roll-out plan to reach missed/underserved communities. WHO, UNICEF and GAVI are currently negotiating with the Ministry of Health in implementation and monitoring of activities for the roll-out of COVID_19 vaccines and routine immunization. These discussions aimed at: (i) securing consent to deliver key health and immunization services through a combination of public and private/INGO/NGO health service providers, ensuring ability to deliver at requisite scale; and (ii) adherence to the principles and priorities of National Vaccine Deployment Plan or roll-out of COVID-19 vaccines, ensuring equity and epidemiological impact.

title.narrative: System for regular monitoring and supervision of vaccinators / FHWs in priority areas is in place, allowing for assessing trend in performance

target.value: Provided support in recruitment of additional human resources at underserved areas and strengthened supportive supervision mechanism

comment.narrative: EHO mentors are recruited to provide technical support for the underserved areas and ethnic areas. The purposes of EHO mentors' recruitment are to support necessary technical guidance and to supervise vaccinators from EHO areas and prioritized areas. They are aimed to work with UNICEF field officers and partners working at these areas. Due to military takeover during February 2021, there are more tensions between ethnic organizations and military. Hence, close monitoring and supportive supervision could not be conducted due to security concern although providing necessary technical support to these areas.

title.narrative: 1. Developed annual microplan at all levels and supported tailored activities to hard to reach, migratory, peri-urban, conflict affected areas and under performing townships 2. Conducted EPI annual evaluation at all levels 3. Recruited training coordinators and training assistants for training centre.

target.value: Develop, conduct and implement specific strategic plan for reaching hard to reach, migratory, peri-urban and conflict area and under performing townships.

comment.narrative: Due to political situation starting from February 2021, the vaccination activities across all states and regions have been suspended. While waiting for the full resumption of government health services, UNICEF together with WHO are planned to support the continuation of minimum essential health services at 37 townships (22 non-government-controlled areas (Ethnic areas) and 15 townships at Rakhine State). WHO and Unicef field staff will support for the preparation and implementation of specific strategic plan for these areas. It will include routine immunization as well as COVID_19 vaccination to these areas.

target.value: Develop, conduct and implement specific strategic plan for reaching hard to reach, migratory, peri-urban and conflict area and under performing townships.

comment.narrative: Due to political situation starting from February 2021, the vaccination activities across all states and regions have been suspended. While waiting for the full resumption of government health services, UNICEF together with WHO are planned to support the continuation of minimum essential health services at 37 townships (22 non-government-controlled areas (Ethnic areas) and 15 townships at Rakhine State). WHO and Unicef field staff will support for the preparation and implementation of specific strategic plan for these areas. It will include routine immunization as well as COVID_19 vaccination to these areas.

title.narrative: 1. Conducted coordination meeting with other EHOs and local partners and provided technical support for tailored activities. 2. Provided EHOs in planning, implementation and monitoring of integrated PHC services. 3. Recruited additional MWs for strengthening immunization services in 96 prioritized townships. 4. Conducted pre-posting integrated trainings based on local context 5. Follow up recommendations of immunization and surveillance reviews and Joint Appraisal 2019.

target.value: Develop, conduct and implement specific strategic plan for reaching hard to reach, migratory, peri-urban and conflict area and under performing townships.

comment.narrative: Eight EHO mentore are on board and cEPI conducted a meeting with with states/regional health departments and ethnic organizations on 18 November 2020 to work closely with EHOs. cEPI, WHO and Unicef focal persons were attended the meeting. After that introduction meeting, EHO mentors were conducted coordination meetings with their respective ethnic organizations and implementing partners during December and January 2021. It was planned to develop specific strategic plan for these ethnic areas. But due to COVID_19 pandemic and military takeover on 1 February 2021, all activities including coordination with EHOs were paused. It is planned to resume the coordination activities with EHOs and partners starting from June and some has already started.

target.value: Provide technical support in the roll out of Interpersonal Communication Skills trainings to basic health workers as well as ethnic health staff.

comment.narrative: Global Interpersonal Communication training package has been adapted and translated. Training package on Facilitator's guide, Participant's manual, Supportive supervision, FAQ and Reference cards have been developed.

title.narrative: Annual workplan and budgets include interventions to reach zero dose children

target.value: Provided technical support for developing annual workplan and budget including intervention to reach zero dose children; and provided technical guidance for all EPI committee meetings including ICC meetings

comment.narrative: Due to current political situation, the annual workplan could not be developed for all areas although some immunization services are provided by non-CDMers at some areas. In addition, there was no EPI committee meetings after 1 February. Before Military takeover, several committee meetings related to COVID_19 vaccine introduction were conducted; weekly NITAG meetings and COVAX National Coordination Committee meetings for COVID_19 vaccine deployment. In addition, series of technical working groups were conducted in all 8 sub-groups and central TWG meetings were also conducted. But after military takeover, no more committee meetings were conducted.

target.value: Provided technical support for developing annual workplan and budget including intervention to reach zero dose children; and provided technical guidance for all EPI committee meetings including ICC meetings

comment.narrative: The annual workplan could not be developed for all areas in 2021 and almost all immunization activities are disrupted for 5 months during 2021. Annual workplan 2022 including intervention to reach zero dose children to be developed in early 2022. It is due to limited human resources at MOH and competing priority with COVID_19 vaccination.

title.narrative: ICC/HSCC tracks implementation of annual workplan (% execution of activities and budgets) and provides oversight to course correction measures

target.value: Provided technical support for developing annual workplan and budget including intervention to reach zero dose children; and provided technical guidance for all EPI committee meetings including ICC meetings

comment.narrative: ICC/HSCC are not functioning after military coup. It may be necessary to reprogram the activity if ICC/HSCC will not functioning in future. WHO and UNICEF are trying to resume the functions of technical working group for routine immunization as well as for COVID_19 vaccination in the country.

target.value: In November 2020 Myanmar will hold another general democratic election, which presents an opportunity to expand and deepen political commitment to undertake health systems reforms, in particular health financing, and social support for these reforms. To take advantage of this opportunity, there is a further need to raise awareness and build shared understanding and consensus among the various stakeholders in health prior to and after the elections. In addition, this presents also another opportunity to strengthen coordination and collaboration across health donors and development partners involved in financing health in Myanmar. Myanmar?s stakeholders?government officials, non-governmental organizations, private sector, ethnic health providers, and civil society?desire and are motivated for learning and reflecting on the successes and failures of other countries, and for consensus building to work together towards UHC goals. As such, there are opportunities to further raise awareness, support knowledge-sharing and lessons learned garnered over recent reforms efforts and initiatives, and build skills to address UHC challenges and develop solutions through workshops, seminars, and peer-to-peer exchanges with other countries.

comment.narrative: Major delay: The advent of the bloody military coup since Feb 1 has led to a shut down of the engagement space with the government. All major health partners and NGOs have either paused or suspended their programs and collaboration with MoHS under current de facto authorities. With the completely different political and operating context, the approach and content of the previous draft TA plan - which were consulted with key stakeholders of that time - needed to be signficiantly revamped based on the shifting and emerging delivery models, actors and their TA needs; and within the constrained parameters of the development partners and implementation agencies. The revised TA plan will speak to the rapidly emerging TA needs of the DPs and non-government health actors, while also being flexible enough to respond to the very dynamic and in-flux operating environment. Several discussions are already underway for the Bank to provide tailored TA to the major health DPs' initiatives to deliver essential health services through alternative arrangements, incl. integration of learning agenda from the outset in the DPs' program. While the overall TA plan is being retooled, the Bank - in collaboration with WHO and P4H - had delivered a just-in-time capacity building training for the staff of major DPs and implementing partners on "Health Financing Basics in Distressed Contexts", focusing on the resource allocation and purchasing arrangements in fragile and conflict affected situations, bringing in relevant recent examples from other countries. The Bank team also provided a consult to ACCESS Fund Management Office on their design thinking and use of program data.

target.value: In November 2020 Myanmar will hold another general democratic election, which presents an opportunity to expand and deepen political commitment to undertake health systems reforms, in particular health financing, and social support for these reforms. To take advantage of this opportunity, there is a further need to raise awareness and build shared understanding and consensus among the various stakeholders in health prior to and after the elections. In addition, this presents also another opportunity to strengthen coordination and collaboration across health donors and development partners involved in financing health in Myanmar. Myanmar?s stakeholders?government officials, non-governmental organizations, private sector, ethnic health providers, and civil society?desire and are motivated for learning and reflecting on the successes and failures of other countries, and for consensus building to work together towards UHC goals. As such, there are opportunities to further raise awareness, support knowledge-sharing and lessons learned garnered over recent reforms efforts and initiatives, and build skills to address UHC challenges and develop solutions through workshops, seminars, and peer-to-peer exchanges with other countries.

The Bank team also provided a consult to ACCESS Fund Management Office on their design thinking and use of program data.

target.value: In November 2020 Myanmar will hold another general democratic election, which presents an opportunity to expand and deepen political commitment to undertake health systems reforms, in particular health financing, and social support for these reforms. To take advantage of this opportunity, there is a further need to raise awareness and build shared understanding and consensus among the various stakeholders in health prior to and after the elections. In addition, this presents also another opportunity to strengthen coordination and collaboration across health donors and development partners involved in financing health in Myanmar. Myanmar?s stakeholders?government officials, non-governmental organizations, private sector, ethnic health providers, and civil society?desire and are motivated for learning and reflecting on the successes and failures of other countries, and for consensus building to work together towards UHC goals. As such, there are opportunities to further raise awareness, support knowledge-sharing and lessons learned garnered over recent reforms efforts and initiatives, and build skills to address UHC challenges and develop solutions through workshops, seminars, and peer-to-peer exchanges with other countries.

comment.narrative: Original TA plan was revised and folded into the broader ASA program for FY 22 (July 21 - Jun 22), after several dialgoues with the key health implementing partners in country (e.g., A2H, PRs and SRs of Global Fund, WHO, USAID, P4H, etc.). Tailored TA and capacity building focus on supporting a few key implementing partners in the areas of implementation research, strategic purchasing, monitoring essential services, and private sector engagement. Implementation of ASA program is in good progress - conducted several bilateral consultation meetings with key implementing agencies to identify TA needs; organized learning events on strategic purchasing in constrained settings and NGOs contracting of lab services with private sector; provided technical inputs and embedded an international consultant to work with a major health funding mechanism (Access to Health/A2H) on design and set up of strategic purchasing program; development in process of IR agenda for A2Hs strategic purchasing program; and carried out just-in-time private sector assessment to meet the information gaps of the health partners.

title.narrative: Township level planning and budgeting workshps completed in pilot townships.

target.value: Planning and budgeting deficits at the subnational level presents as one of the weakest links in the PFM cycle, leading to inefficient allocation and utilization of budget at the frontlines of service delivery. Communication and skills gaps, along with lack of proper SOPs and guidance, among programs and budget divisions responsible for allocating and executing the budget led to poorly prepared budgets and subsequent underspending while gaps in PHC service delivery left unfilled on the ground. MOHS/NIMU under NHP 2017-21 aimed to introduce inclusive Township Health Planning (iTHP) process to address this planning and budgeting deficit at the township level. However, with NHP into third year of implementation, progress on this front - agreement on the process, guidelines and template for participatory township level planning AND training and roll out of the reform is yet to be seen. TCA will support (i) Development of SOPs and templates for township level budget planning (based on draft iTHP guidelines and existing Township Microplan, Immunization Microplan; and integrating experience from planning under 3MDG Fund and Gavi' CTHP; (ii) Training of pilot state/region, and township MOHS staff and key CSO/NGO partners on the ground on the use of SOPs and planning tools at State/Region level; (iii) Individual township planning workshops at selected townships; and (iv) On-site and online coaching and mentoring to the townships to finalize the plans (integrated to the extent possible ? i.e., including government, IDA, Gavi and other resources) in order to be able to provide timely inputs to the annual budget cycle of GoM.

comment.narrative: Major delay: The advent of the bloody military coup since Feb 1 has led to a shut down of the engagement space with the government. All major health partners and NGOs have either paused or suspended their programs and collaboration with MoHS under current de facto authorities. With the completely different political and operating context, the approach and content of the previous draft TA plan - which were consulted with key stakeholders of that time - needed to be signficiantly revamped based on the shifting and emerging delivery models, actors and their TA needs; and within the constrained parameters of the development partners and implementation agencies. The revised TA plan will speak to the rapidly emerging TA needs of the DPs and non-government health actors, while also being flexible enough to respond to the very dynamic and in-flux operating environment. Several discussions are already underway for the Bank to provide tailored TA to the major health DPs' initiatives to deliver essential health services through alternative arrangements, incl. integration of learning agenda from the outset in the DPs' program. While the overall TA plan is being retooled, the Bank - in collaboration with WHO and P4H - had delivered a just-in-time capacity building training for the staff of major DPs and implementing partners on "Health Financing Basics in Distressed Contexts", focusing on the resource allocation and purchasing arrangements in fragile and conflict affected situations, bringing in relevant recent examples from other countries. The Bank team also provided a consult to ACCESS Fund Management Office on their design thinking and use of program data.

title.narrative: Township level mulityear plans with detailed annual budget for 1st year developed, reviewed and finalized by MOHS.

title.narrative: SOPs and templates for township health planning and budgeting process developed/adpated and agreed to by MOHS. Training of pilot S/R and townships completed.

title.narrative: Preliminary summary of first year of data

target.value: Assessment of impact and effectiveness of rotavirus vaccine in Myanmar

comment.narrative: Major Delays - Political instability has interrupted surveillance at all sentinel sites. We remain in contact with PIs in country and are working to try to find a solution for restarting surviellance when possible. Cleaning of data from prior to the surviellance interuption has also been disrupted which in turn has delayed a summary of the limited data available for the first year of surveillance.

target.value: Assessment of impact and effectiveness of rotavirus vaccine in Myanmar

comment.narrative: Minor Delays - Political instability has slowed data cleaning activities within the country which in turn has delayed a summary of the first year of data. Activities continue as able and once on initial round of data cleaning has been conducted, a preliminary summary of the data will be produced.

target.value: Assessment of impact and effectiveness of rotavirus vaccine in Myanmar

comment.narrative: Minor Delays - Political instability has slowed data cleaning activities within the country which in turn has delayed a summary of the first year of data. Activities continue as able and once on initial round of data cleaning has been conducted, a preliminary summary of the data will be produced.

title.narrative: Completion of first round of data cleaning

target.value: Assessment of impact and effectiveness of rotavirus vaccine in Myanmar

comment.narrative: Minor Delays - Surveillance is ongoing but has been slowed due to political instability in the country. Good communication remains between partners and activities to review surveillance activities, assess data quality, and clean data will continue as the situation allows.

target.value: Assessment of impact and effectiveness of rotavirus vaccine in Myanmar

comment.narrative: Minor Delays on conducting program evaluation. STOP membes stayed in country for most of 2020, had a break in January and returned to country. Evaluation planned for q 4 2021

title.narrative: [Y/N] Strategy and timeline for scaling-up supply chain data system (e.g. RTM, eLMIS) developed, including sections on handover of system management, financial costs and maintenance presented to government;

target.value: Effective vaccine management improvement plan implementation through installation of Remote Temperature Monitoring Devices (RTMD) in cold chain equipment at sub-depots and 330 township cold stores.

comment.narrative: Partnership agreement was signed with Clinton Health Access Initiatives Myanmar (CHAI) to implement eLMIS for immunization and public health commodities over the project period from February 2021 to August 2022. Following military taking over, most government staff joined civil disobedience movement including the national immunization program. This left the project without project governing body from the ministry side who was supposed to technically oversight the project activities. However, coordination meetings with UNFPA, Chemonics and Zenith TRI were conducted to better understand about different eLMIS projects for effective collaboration among supply chain stakeholders in the country. Orientation sessions to CHAI project team were facilitated by UNICEF as well to have in depth understanding about immunization supply chain tools and current paper based system. With this, CHAI project team has been reviewing the customization and data visualization with the mSupply foundation. Given current situation which may last longer, UNICEF and CHAI will discuss an alternate plan to revise the project scope, timeline, budget and some key activities. RTMD implementation developed with detailed guidelines and purchase requisition placed

title.narrative: Complete second round of data cleaning

target.value: Assessment of impact and effectiveness of rotavirus vaccine in Myanmar

comment.narrative: Political instability has interrupted surveillance at all sentinel sites. CDC remains in contact with PIs in country and are working to try to find a solution for restarting surveillance when possible. Cleaning of data from prior to the surveillance interruption has also been disrupted.

title.narrative: Complete first round of data cleaning

target.value: Assessment of impact and effectiveness of rotavirus vaccine in Myanmar

comment.narrative: Political instability has interrupted surveillance at all sentinel sites. CDC remains in contact with PIs in country and are working to try to find a solution for restarting surveillance when possible. Cleaning of data from prior to the surveillance interruption has also been disrupted.

target.value: Assessment of impact and effectiveness of rotavirus vaccine in Myanmar

comment.narrative: Surveillance is ongoing but has been been slowed due to political instability in the country. Good communication remains between partners and activities to review surveillance activities, assess data quality, and clean data will continue as the situation allows.

title.narrative: Service delivery related barriers of missed communities to access immunisation services identified and prioritized

target.value: Provide technical assistance in development of long term agreement with the suppliers for electrification of selected rural health centers in Myanmar, support tendering process and technical evaluation of the suppliers

comment.narrative: Term of Reference for Institutional Contract finalized detailing 1. required tasks with acceptable technical requirements of power outputs, solar panel and mounting structures and accessories, 2. end product/deliverables and 3. expected duration/timeline to be completed for Design (suggested three designs to suit for different geographical contexts and land/building nature), Procure and supply system components and installation of Electrification of Health Facilities. This is incorporated as one of lots to be submitted for long term agreement. Because of political context, pre-bid meeting for tendering with potential institutions was carried out in the first week of November. Technical evaluation will be done after receipt of technical and financial proposals with supporting documents by potential institutions in late November 2021. In addition, selected sites will be reviewed in line with current operation contexts

title.narrative: EVM Assessment results available showing improvement in composite score

target.value: Consultative workshop on Effective vaccine management Assessment (EVMA) and dissemination workshop on the EVMA results and continuous improvement plan . This requires regular follow up on the implementation of IP at National/Sub-National Level.

comment.narrative: The implementation progress against the EVM improvement plan (2016-2021) was reviewed by the international cold chain consultant through desk review of the available documents and information. The final report was received which indicated areas where substantial progress has been made, and also made recommendations for some of the activities which needs to be fast tracked when the country's situation improves and before next formal EVM assessment.

title.narrative: 1. Data Quality self assessement completed 2. Technical support provided for EVM assessment

target.value: Technical support for improvement of data quality

comment.narrative: Due to current political situation, data quality self assessment and EVM assessments could not be conducted as planned. It may not happen also in 2022.

title.narrative: 1. Data Quality self assessement completed 2. Technical support provided for EVM assessment

target.value: Technical support for improvement of data quality

comment.narrative: With technical support of WHO, MoHS has decided to deploy the Sante MPI software for developing unique ID, client registration (socio-demographic data), and to adopt the DHIS2 COVID vaccination packages for service delivery (recording vaccine information, stock management, AEFI tracking) for COVID_19 vaccination throughout the country. By taking this opportunity, WHO and MoHS planned to improve the data quality of immunization services in the country by establishing digital immunization system. But after Military takeover, no longer use of MPI software by current authority; and DHIS2 software for COVID_19 vaccination was not utilized properly and timely by non-CDMers.

target.value: Technical support for improvement of data quality

comment.narrative: With technical support of WHO, MoHS has decided to deploy the Sante MPI software for developing unique ID, client registration (socio-demographic data), and to adopt the DHIS2 COVID vaccination packages for service delivery (recording vaccine information, stock management, AEFI tracking) for COVID_19 vaccination throughout the country. By taking this opportunity, WHO and MoHS planned to improve the data quality of immunization services in the country by establishing digital immunization system. But after Military takeover, no longer use of MPI software by current authority; and DHIS2 software for COVID_19 vaccination was not utilized properly and timely by non-CDMers.

title.narrative: 1. Prepared for Data Quality self assessment and EVM assessment 2. Supported for DHIS 2 software user extension 3. Operational Research on Routine Immunization at State/ Regional level conducted

target.value: Technical support for improvement of data quality

title.narrative: 1. EPI digital package installed 2. Data quality app installed 3. EPI legacy data migrated 4. Training given

target.value: Support transitioning to DHIS2 for EPI

comment.narrative: Focussed on Covax up to now, reprogramming/replanning the existing configuration.

title.narrative: Transition plan for EPI in place with agreed date for end of parallel system Costed scale up plan exist

target.value: Support transitioning to DHIS2 for EPI
